posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
Does anyone have a recommendation for an easy-to-interface beam breaker sensor? Need to detect when we have actually acquired game pieces.

We have some old ones lying around, but wondering what people are using these days.

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: Our team is using AdaFruit sensors right now

link_counts.title: IR Break Beam Sensor with Premium Wire Header Ends - 5mm LEDs : ID 2168 : $5.95 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits

posts.cooked: I think we use these too, we have never had a problem with them

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: We use these too and they‚Äôre great. Easy to interface and reliable. Oh, and they‚Äôre cheap too.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: E18-D80NK, from HiLetGo with pre-crimped connectors. Better than a beam break because you don‚Äôt need to align a second half. It trips when an object gets within an adjustable trigger range. Also has a threaded body for adjustment.

We used these same sensors last year to detect balls in the robot. Very happy with them, super easy to use and adjust.

HiLetgo 3pcs E18-D80NK Infrared Photoelectric Switch Obstacle Avoidance Sensor Module: Amazon.com: Industrial & Scientific

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked: 3468 has also used these IR Photoelectric Reflection sensors to good effect!

posts.name: Leo
posts.cooked: I highly recommend these adafruit sensors. I‚Äôve had problems before with the e18-d80nk sensors breaking/being less reliable than beam break sensors, and the adafruit ones are cheap and work amazingly well.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Banner Engineering sensors (QS18 series or similar) are pricey but very reliable.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: Using these now, they‚Äôre great. Only issue is ours is rated for minimum distance of 3mm but setting the tuning screw past the 3" sensing point causes it to not sense anything at all. Not sure if it‚Äôs just our model or the product in general but it‚Äôs something to be aware of.

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: My team used these before and they worked amazingly. I would recommend that you be careful with the wires though, they do come out of their casing pretty easily if you don‚Äôt leave enough slack

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
You might have already seen these on our past robots

This small digital distance sensor detects objects between 2¬†cm and 10¬†cm (0.8‚Ä≥ and 4‚Ä≥) away. With its quick response time, small size, and low current draw, this sensor is a good choice for non-contact object detection, and our compact...

They come in 3 ranges.

Strictly speaking they don‚Äôt detect break the beam but detect when the beam is made by reflectance. The sender and receiver are in the same small package and don‚Äôt require a device on both sides of the object to be detected. That‚Äôs why they have to come in various ranges.

They are available at various robotics shops.

link_counts.title: Pololu Carrier with Sharp GP2Y0D810Z0F Digital Distance Sensor 10cm

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: for the adafruit sensors, how hard is it to align them properly? Since they are so small, has anyone run into difficulty mounting them?

posts.name: Josh (he/him)
posts.cooked:
My team has had success with putting a status indicator for the sensor on our robot dashboard and referencing that when installing them on the robot. We generally attach each end of the sensor to a plate, clamp one plate on a tube where we think we want the sensor, and then bring the other end into position using the dashboard feedback.

I‚Äôm not sure how tolerant of misalignment the sensors are, but we haven‚Äôt struggled too much when using them the last couple years with the above process.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: In my experience using them, they aren‚Äôt exactly pin-point, so there‚Äôs a small cone of detection that gets created the further they are from each other, likely with a fall off at some point. But the point being that if you have them a foot or more away from each other, the actually aren‚Äôt hard to align.

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
We also use the Adafruit beam breaks.

We were wondering if it was possible to attach these directly to a FalconFX limit switch. I have a mentor that thinks it should be possible, haven‚Äôt found any documentation to support or refute this. Planning to test this.

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked: Thanks to all for the suggestions. I think we have some of the Sharp sensors (I used them for programmer training), our electrical mentor had some Banners stowed away that I didn‚Äôt know about, and I have both the Adafruit and the E180D80NK on the way.
